abstract.p: University of California's men's heavyweight varsity successfully defends Intercollegiate Rowing Association title (S)

block.p: California's men's heavyweight varsity repeated as national collegiate champion, successfully defending its Intercollegiate Rowing Association title yesterday in Cherry Hill, N.J., with a finesse that left the five other boats in the final to battle for the runner-up spot.

Top-seeded Cal paced itself against second-seeded Brown for the first 1,000 meters of the 2,000-meter Cooper River course, then in 10 strokes drew away from the Bruins. Cal cruised home in 5 minutes 39.5 seconds, a full five seconds, or more than a boat length, ahead of Brown.

California's men's heavyweight varsity repeated as national collegiate champion, successfully defending its Intercollegiate Rowing Association title yesterday in Cherry Hill, N.J., with a finesse that left the five other boats in the final to battle for the runner-up spot.

Top-seeded Cal paced itself against second-seeded Brown for the first 1,000 meters of the 2,000-meter Cooper River course, then in 10 strokes drew away from the Bruins. Cal cruised home in 5 minutes 39.5 seconds, a full five seconds, or more than a boat length, ahead of Brown.
Princeton fell three-tenths of a second short of Brown for third. Washington lost to Cal for the fourth time this season, finishing fourth, followed by Temple and Dartmouth.
Cal defeated Washington and Wisconsin to capture the freshmen race, but placed fourth in the junior varsity contest, giving Brown the only East Coast victory in the heavyweight races.

Yale's men's lightweight varsity won the closest finish of the day, avenging an 0.11-second loss to Columbia two weeks ago in the Eastern Sprints. The top four finishers were within a second of one another, with the Elis winning in 5:30.39.
